Pension Schemes Act 2021
2021 CHAPTER 1
An Act to make provision about pension schemes.
[11th February 2021]

Be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the adviceand consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this presentParliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—
PART 1Collective money purchase benefits
Definitions
Collective money purchase benefits and schemes
For the purposes of this Part, a benefit provided under a pension scheme isa “collective money purchase benefit” if—
the benefit is a qualifying benefit (see section 2), and
the scheme is a qualifying scheme (see sections 3 and 4).
In this Part “collective money purchase scheme” means—
a qualifying scheme, or
a section of a qualifying scheme (see sections 3(6) to (9) and 5),
under which all of the benefits that may be provided are qualifying benefits.
Qualifying benefits
A benefit provided under a pension scheme is a “qualifying benefit” if—
the benefit is provided out of the available assets of the scheme,

under the rules of the scheme, the rate or amount of the benefit is subjectto periodic adjustments designed to achieve a balance between the value of theavailable assets of the scheme and the required amount, and
the benefit is not of a description specified in regulations made by theSecretary of State.
In subsection (1)—
* “the available assets of the scheme” means all the assets that—
arise or derive from the payments made by or in respect of members of thescheme, and
are available (subject to any deductions that fall to be made in respect ofadministration charges) for the provision of benefits to or in respect of themembers of the scheme collectively;

* “the required amount” means the amount expected to be required, applying appropriate actuarial assumptions, for the purpose of providing benefits under the scheme to or in respect of the members of the scheme collectively.
Regulations under subsection (1)(c) are subject to affirmative resolutionprocedure.
Where a scheme is divided into sections, this section has effect as if—
the reference to the scheme in subsection (1)(a) were a reference to asection of the scheme, and
the other references to the scheme were references to that section of it.
Qualifying schemes
A pension scheme is a “qualifying scheme” if it meets the requirements inthis section.

The scheme must be an occupational pension scheme established under anirrevocable trust by a person or persons to whom section 1(2)(a) (employer) ofthe Pension Schemes Act 1993 applied when the scheme was established (withoutother persons).
The scheme must be used, or intended to be used, only by—
a single employer, or
two or more employers that are connected with each other.
The scheme must not be a relevant public service pension scheme (seesection 4).
The qualifying benefits provided under the scheme must consist of orinclude the payment of a pension.
If the scheme provides both qualifying benefits and other benefits, theremust be appropriate separation of the qualifying benefits.
There is “appropriate separation” of qualifying benefits and other benefitsif (and only if)—
the scheme is divided into sections,
none of the sections under which qualifying benefits are provided providesother types of benefit,
payments made by or in respect of members of the scheme for the purpose ofproviding qualifying benefits under a section of the scheme are allocated tothat section, and
a proportion of the assets of the scheme is attributable to each section ofthe scheme and cannot be used for the purposes of any other section.

If the scheme provides a combination of qualifying benefits with differentcharacteristics that is described in regulations made by the Secretary ofState, there must be appropriate separation of those qualifying benefits.
There is “appropriate separation” of qualifying benefits with differentcharacteristics if (and only if)—
the scheme is divided into sections,
each of the different types of qualifying benefit is provided under adifferent section,
payments made by or in respect of members of the scheme for the purpose ofproviding qualifying benefits under a section of the scheme are allocated tothat section, and
a proportion of the assets of the scheme is attributable to each section ofthe scheme and cannot be used for the purposes of any other section.
Regulations under subsection (8) are subject to negative resolutionprocedure.
Qualifying schemes: supplementary
For the purposes of section 3(4) a pension scheme is a relevant publicservice pension scheme if it is—
a public service pension scheme within the meaning of the Pension SchemesAct 1993 (see section 1(1) of that Act),
a scheme under section 1 of the Public Service Pensions Act 2013 (newpublic service schemes),
a new public body pension scheme as defined in section 30 of that Act, or
a statutory pension scheme that is connected with a scheme referred to inparagraph (b) or (c).
In subsection (1)(d) “connected” and “statutory pension scheme” have thesame meaning as in the Public Service Pensions Act 2013 (see sections 4(6) and37 of that Act).
The reference to a pension in section 3(5) does not include incomewithdrawal or dependants’ income withdrawal within the meaning of paragraphs 7and 21 of Schedule 28 to the Finance Act 2004.
Schemes divided into sections
The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about when apension scheme is or is not divided into sections for the purposes of thisPart.

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide that, where a collectivemoney purchase scheme that is not divided into sections (an “undividedscheme”) becomes a collective money purchase scheme that is divided intosections, an authorisation previously granted in respect of the undividedscheme applies to any of those sections that—
is a collective money purchase scheme by reason of section 1(2)(b), and
satisfies conditions specified in the regulations.
For the purposes of this Part, where—
a qualifying scheme is divided into sections, and
each of those sections is a collective money purchase scheme by reason ofsection 1(2)(b),
the qualifying scheme (taken as a whole) is to be treated as if it were not acollective money purchase scheme.
Regulations under subsection (1) are subject to negative resolutionprocedure.
Regulations under subsection (2) are subject to affirmative resolutionprocedure.
Amendment of definitions of “money purchase benefits” etc
Schedule 1 contains amendments of definitions of “money purchase benefits”in—
Schedule 10A to the Building Societies Act 1986 (disclosures aboutdirectors, other officers and employees in notes to accounts);
the Pension Schemes Act 1993;
Part 1 of the Pensions Act 2008 (pension scheme membership for jobholders).
In section 32 of the Pensions Act 2011 (power to amend definitions of“money purchase benefits” in certain Acts)—
in subsection (1)—
for “purpose the” substitute “purpose—
the”;
at the end insert “, or
section 2 of the Pension Schemes Act 2021 (collective money purchasebenefits: meaning of “qualifying benefits”).”;
in subsection (2), at the end insert “or by Schedule 1 to the PensionSchemes Act 2021”.
Authorisation
Authorisation of collective money purchase schemes
A person may not operate a collective money purchase scheme unless thescheme is authorised.
Section 10 of the Pensions Act 1995 (civil penalties) applies to a personwho breaches subsection (1).
If the Pensions Regulator becomes aware that a collective money purchasescheme is being operated without authorisation, it must notify the trustees ofthe scheme that the scheme is not authorised.
The notification must—
explain that the notification is a triggering event (see section 31), and
include an explanation of the trustees’ duties under sections 31 to 45.
For the purposes of this section a person “operates” a collective moneypurchase scheme if, in relation to the scheme, the person accepts—
money paid by a member (or prospective member), or
money paid by an employer (or prospective employer) in respect ofcontributions, fees, charges or anything else except—
the costs of setting up the scheme, or
costs relating to obtaining authorisation for the scheme.
Application for authorisation
The trustees of a collective money purchase scheme may apply to thePensions Regulator for authorisation.
An application must be made in the manner and form specified by thePensions Regulator.
An application must include—
the scheme’s viability report and viability certificate (see section 13),and
the scheme’s continuity strategy (see section 17).
The Secretary of State may by regulations—
specify other information that must be included in an application;
require a fee to be paid to the Pensions Regulator in respect of anapplication.
In considering an application, the Pensions Regulator may take into accountany matters it considers appropriate, including—
additional information provided by the applicant, and
subsequent changes to the application or to any information provided by theapplicant.
Regulations under subsection (4) are subject to negative resolutionprocedure.
Decision on application

Where an application is made for authorisation of a collective moneypurchase scheme under section 8, the Pensions Regulator must decide whether itis satisfied that the scheme meets the authorisation criteria.
The Pensions Regulator must make that decision within the period of sixmonths beginning with the day on which the Pensions Regulator received theapplication.
The authorisation criteria are—
that the persons involved in the scheme are fit and proper persons (seesection 11),
that the design of the scheme is sound (see section 12),
that the scheme is financially sustainable (see section 14),
that the scheme has adequate systems and processes for communicating withmembers and others (see section 15),
that the systems and processes used in running the scheme are sufficient toensure that it is run effectively (see section 16), and
that the scheme has an adequate continuity strategy (see section 17).
If the Pensions Regulator is satisfied that the collective money purchasescheme meets the authorisation criteria, it must—
grant the authorisation,
notify the applicant of its decision, and
add the scheme to its list of authorised collective money purchase schemes(see section 26).
If the Pensions Regulator is not satisfied that the collective moneypurchase scheme meets the authorisation criteria, it must—
refuse to grant the authorisation, and
notify the applicant of its decision.
A notification under subsection (5)(b) must also include—
the reasons for the decision, and
details of the right of referral to the First-tier Tribunal or UpperTribunal (see section 10).
Reference to Tribunal of refusal to grant authorisation
If the Pensions Regulator refuses to grant authorisation to a collectivemoney purchase scheme, the decision may be referred to the Tribunal by—
the trustees, or
any other person who appears to the Tribunal to be directly affected by thedecision.
In this section “the Tribunal”, in relation to a reference under subsection(1), means—
the First-tier Tribunal, in any case where it is determined by or underTribunal Procedure Rules that the First-tier Tribunal is to hear thereference;
the Upper Tribunal, in any other case.
Authorisation criteria
Fit and proper persons requirement

This section applies for the purposes of enabling the Pensions Regulator todecide whether it is satisfied that the persons involved in a collective moneypurchase scheme are fit and proper persons (see section 9(3)(a)).
The Pensions Regulator must assess whether each of the following is a fitand proper person to act in relation to the scheme in the capacity mentioned—
a person who establishes the scheme;
a trustee;
a person who (alone or with others) has power to appoint or remove atrustee;
a person who (alone or with others) has power to vary the provisions of thescheme;
a person acting in a capacity specified in regulations made by theSecretary of State.
In assessing whether a person is a fit and proper person to act in aparticular capacity, the Pensions Regulator—
must take into account any matters specified in regulations made by theSecretary of State, and
may take into account such other matters as it considers appropriate,including matters relating to a person connected with that person.
Regulations under subsection (3)(a) may include provision requiringspecified information to be provided to the Pensions Regulator.
For the purposes of this section, a person (“A”) is connected with anotherperson (“B”) if—
A is an associate of B;
where B is a company, A is a director or shadow director of B or anassociate of a director or shadow director of B;
A is a trustee of an occupational pension scheme established under a trustand—
the beneficiaries of the trust include B or an associate of B, or
the provisions of the scheme confer a power that may be exercised for thebenefit of B or an associate of B.
In this section—
* “associate” has the meaning given in section 435 of the Insolvency Act 1986;
* “director” and “shadow director” have the meaning given in section 251 of that Act.
Regulations under subsection (3)(a) are subject to affirmative resolutionprocedure.
Regulations under subsection (2)(e) are subject to negative resolutionprocedure.
Scheme design requirement
This section applies for the purposes of enabling the Pensions Regulator todecide whether it is satisfied that the design of a collective money purchasescheme is sound (see section 9(3)(b)).
In deciding whether the design of a collective money purchase scheme issound, the Pensions Regulator must take into account—
the scheme’s viability report and viability certificate (see section 13);
any matters specified in regulations made by the Secretary of State.
Regulations under subsection (2)(b) may include provision requiringspecified information to be provided to the Pensions Regulator.
Regulations under subsection (2)(b) are subject to affirmative resolutionprocedure.
Viability report
The trustees of a collective money purchase scheme must—
prepare a document explaining the design of the scheme and the reasons thatthey consider the design to be sound (a “viability report”), and
obtain a certificate from the scheme actuary certifying that, in theactuary’s opinion, the design of the scheme is sound (a “viabilitycertificate”).
The scheme actuary may not give a viability certificate unless satisfiedthat the scheme has rules that meet the requirements of section 18 and anyregulations under that section.
The Secretary of State may by regulations—
specify information that must be included in a viability report,
specify other requirements with which a viability report must comply,
make provision about the content of a viability certificate,
specify matters to which the scheme actuary must have regard when providinga viability certificate, and
make provision about additional information or documents that must beprepared or obtained in connection with a viability report.
The trustees of a collective money purchase scheme must, at least once ayear—
review the most recent viability report,
if appropriate, revise it, and
obtain a new viability certificate in respect of the report (or revisedreport).
If the most recent viability report becomes inaccurate or incomplete to anysignificant extent, the trustees must—
revise the report, and
obtain a new viability certificate in respect of the revised report.
The trustees must provide the Pensions Regulator with the information anddocuments listed in subsection (7)—
on applying for authorisation (see section 8),
within three months of the viability report being revised, and
at any other time, on request from the Pensions Regulator.
The information and documents to be provided are—
the most recent viability report;
the most recent viability certificate;
any additional information or documents specified or described inregulations under subsection (3)(e).
Regulations under subsection (3) are subject to affirmative resolutionprocedure.
Financial sustainability requirement
This section applies for the purposes of enabling the Pensions Regulator todecide whether it is satisfied that a collective money purchase scheme isfinancially sustainable (see section 9(3)(c)).

In order to be satisfied that a collective money purchase scheme isfinancially sustainable, the Pensions Regulator must be satisfied that thescheme has sufficient financial resources to meet the following costs—
the costs of setting up and running the scheme, and
in the event of a triggering event occurring—
the costs of complying with the duties under sections 31 to 45, and
the costs of continuing to run the scheme for such period (which must beat least six months and no more than two years) as the Pensions Regulatorthinks appropriate for the scheme.

In deciding whether it is satisfied that a scheme has sufficient financialresources to meet the costs mentioned in subsection (2), the PensionsRegulator must take into account any matters specified in regulations made bythe Secretary of State.
Regulations under subsection (3) may include provision—
requiring specified information to be provided to the Pensions Regulator;
specifying requirements to be met by the scheme relating to its financing,such as requirements relating to assets, capital or liquidity.
Regulations under subsection (3) are subject to affirmative resolutionprocedure.
Communication requirement

This section applies for the purposes of enabling the Pensions Regulator todecide whether it is satisfied that a collective money purchase scheme hasadequate systems and processes for communicating with members and others (seesection 9(3)(d)).

In order to be satisfied that a scheme has adequate systems and processesfor communicating with members and others, the Pensions Regulator must besatisfied that the scheme has adequate systems and processes—
for providing information in relation to the scheme to persons fallingwithin subsection (3);
for securing that information provided to those persons is correct and isnot misleading.
A person falls within this subsection if the person is—
a member or prospective member of the scheme, or
a person who has survived a member of the scheme and has an entitlement tobenefits, or a right to future benefits, under the scheme rules in respect ofthe member.
In making the decision, the Pensions Regulator—
must take into account any matters specified in regulations made by theSecretary of State, and
may take into account any communications made using the systems andprocesses referred to in subsection (2).
Regulations under subsection (4)(a) may among other things—
make provision about systems and processes used for assessing and improvingthe effectiveness of communications;
make provision requiring specified information to be provided to thePensions Regulator.
Regulations under subsection (4)(a) are subject to affirmative resolutionprocedure.
Systems and processes requirements

This section applies for the purposes of enabling the Pensions Regulator todecide whether it is satisfied that the systems and processes used in runninga collective money purchase scheme are sufficient to ensure that it is runeffectively (see section 9(3)(e)).

In deciding whether it is satisfied that the systems and processes used inrunning the scheme are sufficient for that purpose, the Pensions Regulatormust take into account any matters specified in regulations made by theSecretary of State.
Regulations under subsection (2) may among other things—
make provision about the matters set out in subsection (4);
require specified information to be provided to the Pensions Regulator.
The matters referred to in subsection (3)(a) are—
features and functionality required of the IT systems used in running thescheme;
standards that those IT systems must meet (for example, in relation toquality and in relation to security of data);
the maintenance of those IT systems;
records management, risk management and resource planning;
processes relating to transactions and investment decisions;
processes relating to the appointment and removal of trustees;
processes relating to the professional development of trustees;
processes relating to the appointment, removal, roles and responsibilitiesof—
persons, other than the trustees, involved in running the scheme, and
persons involved in providing services in relation to the scheme.
Regulations under subsection (2) are subject to affirmative resolutionprocedure.
Continuity strategy requirement

This section applies for the purposes of enabling the Pensions Regulator todecide whether it is satisfied that a collective money purchase scheme has anadequate continuity strategy (see section 9(3)(f)).

The trustees of a collective money purchase scheme must prepare a documentaddressing how the interests of members of the scheme are to be protected if atriggering event (see section 31) occurs in relation to the scheme (a“continuity strategy”).
A continuity strategy must include a section setting out the levels ofadministration charges that apply in relation to members of the scheme.
It must set out those levels of charges in the manner specified inregulations made by the Secretary of State.
A continuity strategy must—
contain such other information as may be specified in regulations made bythe Secretary of State, and
be prepared in accordance with regulations made by the Secretary of State.
The trustees of a collective money purchase scheme must—
keep the continuity strategy under review, and
revise it if appropriate.
The trustees must provide the continuity strategy to the PensionsRegulator—
on application for authorisation (see section 8),
within three months of the continuity strategy being revised, and
at any other time, on request from the Pensions Regulator.
In deciding whether a continuity strategy is adequate, the PensionsRegulator must take into account any matters specified in regulations made bythe Secretary of State.
Regulations under subsection (8) may include provision requiring specifiedinformation to be provided to the Pensions Regulator.
Regulations under this section are subject to affirmative resolutionprocedure.
Valuation and benefit adjustment
Calculation of benefits
A collective money purchase scheme must have rules about how the rate oramount of benefits provided under the scheme is to be determined.
The rules must include—
rules for determining the available assets of the scheme and their value,
rules for determining the required amount, and
rules about how the rate or amount of benefits provided under the scheme isto be adjusted from time to time, including rules about when adjustments areto take effect.
In this section “the available assets of the scheme” and “the requiredamount” have the meaning given in section 2(2).
The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about the mattersmentioned in subsections (1) and (2), including provision about the methodsand assumptions to be used.
Regulations under subsection (4) making provision about the determinationof the required amount may, among other things, make provision about—
how past or proposed adjustments to the rate or amount of benefits providedunder the scheme are to be treated;
assumptions to be made about future adjustments to the rate or amount ofsuch benefits.
Regulations under subsection (4) may, among other things—
provide for alternative methods and assumptions;
require or enable the trustees to decide which methods and assumptions areto be used;
specify matters that the trustees must take into account, or principlesthey must follow, in making such decisions.
Regulations under subsection (4)—
may make provision applying in relation to rights under the scheme thathave already accrued;
override the rules of the scheme to the extent that the rules conflict withthe regulations.
Regulations under subsection (4) are subject to affirmative resolutionprocedure.
Advice of scheme actuary

The trustees of a collective money purchase scheme must obtain the adviceof the scheme actuary before making a decision as to the methods andassumptions to be used in determining the matters mentioned in section 18(1)and (2).
The Secretary of State may by regulations specify requirements with whichthe scheme actuary must comply when advising the trustees in accordance withsubsection (1).

Regulations under subsection (2) may, among other things, require thescheme actuary to have regard to guidance that is prepared, and from time totime revised, by a person specified or described in the regulations.
Section 10 of the Pensions Act 1995 (civil penalties) applies to a trusteewho fails to take all reasonable steps to comply with subsection (1).
The first regulations under subsection (2) are subject to affirmativeresolution procedure.
Subsequent regulations under subsection (2) are subject to negativeresolution procedure.
Actuarial valuations
The trustees of a collective money purchase scheme must obtain actuarialvaluations in accordance with this section and regulations under subsection(5).
In this Part “actuarial valuation” means a report prepared and signed bythe scheme actuary setting out—
the available assets of the scheme and their value;
the required amount;
whether an adjustment to the rate or amount of benefits provided under thescheme is required and, if so, the amount of the adjustment.
In this section “the available assets of the scheme” and “the requiredamount” have the meaning given in section 2(2).
A scheme actuary preparing an actuarial valuation in pursuance of aprovision of this Part must determine the matters mentioned in subsection (2)in accordance with the scheme rules.
The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about actuarialvaluations, including—
provision about when actuarial valuations must be prepared;
provision about the date by reference to which a determination must bemade;
provision about information and statements that an actuarial valuation mustcontain;
provision requiring the trustees to obtain an actuarial valuation from thescheme actuary within a period specified or described in the regulations;
provision requiring the trustees to send an actuarial valuation received bythem to the Pensions Regulator within a period specified or described in theregulations.
In a case that is not the subject of regulations under subsection (5)(a),the trustees must obtain—

an actuarial valuation in which the date by reference to which theavailable assets of the scheme are determined (“the effective date”) fallswithin the period of one year beginning with the day on which the scheme wasestablished, and
subsequent actuarial valuations in which the effective date is not morethan one year after the effective date of the previous actuarial valuation.
In a case that is not the subject of regulations under subsection (5)(b),the required amount must be determined by reference to the effective date.
Section 10 of the Pensions Act 1995 (civil penalties) applies to a trusteewho fails to take all reasonable steps to comply with this section.
Nothing in this section affects a power or duty of the trustees of acollective money purchase scheme to obtain actuarial valuations on otheroccasions.
The first regulations under subsection (5) are subject to affirmativeresolution procedure.
Subsequent regulations under subsection (5) are subject to negativeresolution procedure.
Certificate that actuarial valuation prepared in accordance with schemerules

A scheme actuary who prepares an actuarial valuation in pursuance of aprovision of this Part must certify that the matters mentioned in section20(2) have been determined in accordance with the scheme rules.
Benefits adjustments
This section applies where an adjustment to the rate or amount of benefitsprovided under a collective money purchase scheme is required in accordancewith the scheme rules.
The trustees must as soon as is reasonably practicable report in writing tothe Pensions Regulator if the adjustment—
is not made in accordance with the most recent actuarial valuation, or
does not take effect in accordance with the scheme rules.
A report under subsection (2) must—
explain why the adjustment was not made in accordance with the most recentactuarial valuation or (as the case may be) does not take effect in accordancewith the scheme rules;
contain such other information as the Secretary of State may specify inregulations.
Section 10 of the Pensions Act 1995 (civil penalties) applies to a trusteewho fails to take all reasonable steps to comply with this section.
Regulations under subsection (3)(b) are subject to negative resolutionprocedure.
Powers of the Pensions Regulator

The powers conferred by this section are exercisable where it appears tothe Pensions Regulator (as a result of a report made to it or otherwise) thatthe trustees of a collective money purchase scheme have without good reason—
failed to comply with a requirement imposed by or under this Part to obtainan actuarial valuation, or
failed to secure that any adjustment to the rate or amount of benefitsprovided under the scheme which is required in accordance with the schemerules—
is made in accordance with the most recent actuarial valuation, and
takes effect in accordance with the scheme rules.
The Pensions Regulator may direct the trustees—
to obtain an actuarial valuation;
to take such other steps as the Pensions Regulator considers appropriate toremedy or mitigate the failure.
A direction under subsection (2)(a) must—
specify the period within which the valuation is to be obtained;
specify the date by reference to which the matters to be set out in theactuarial valuation are to be determined;
contain such other information as the Secretary of State may specify inregulations.
In exercising a power conferred by this section, the Pensions Regulatormust comply with any requirements specified in regulations made by theSecretary of State.
Section 10 of the Pensions Act 1995 (civil penalties) applies to a trusteewho fails to take all reasonable steps to comply with a direction under thissection.
Regulations under this section are subject to negative resolutionprocedure.
The powers conferred by this section are in addition to any powersexercisable by the Pensions Regulator under any other enactment.

Rules about modifying schemes

in subsection (2)(a)(i), after “if the modification is a protectedmodification,” insert “or the scheme is a collective money purchase schemewithin the meaning of Part 1 of the Pension Schemes Act 2021,”;
in subsection (2)(a)(ii), for “if it is not” substitute “if sub-paragraph(i) does not apply”;
in subsection (3) omit paragraph (b) and the “or” before it;
after subsection (3) insert—
“(3A)Regulations may provide for cases in which the subsisting rightsprovisions do not apply.”
In section 67A (the subsisting rights provisions: interpretation), insubsection (1), before ““regulated modification”” insert—

After subsection (1) of that section insert—
“(1A)“Prohibited modification” means a modification of an occupational pensionscheme which on taking effect would or might result in any subsisting rightof—
a member of the scheme, or
a survivor of a member of the scheme,
which is not a right or entitlement to money purchase benefits becoming, orbeing replaced with, a right or entitlement to collective money purchasebenefits under the scheme rules.”

on taking effect would or might result in a relevant transformation of anysubsisting right of a member of the scheme or a survivor of a member of thescheme (see subsection (3A)),”;

(3B)For the purposes of subsection (3A), the reference in the definition of“money purchase benefits” in section 181(1) of the Pension Schemes Act 1993 tothe widow, widower or surviving civil partner of a member of an occupationalpension scheme is to be read as including any other survivor of the member.”

Transfer rights

In section 97 (calculation of cash equivalents), after subsection (3)insert—

“(3ZA)Where, in the case of an application from a member under section 95 thatrelates to money purchase benefits that are collective money purchasebenefits, regulations under section 99(2)(c) provide for a period longer than6 months, subsection (3)(b) is to be read as if the reference to 6 months werea reference to that longer period.”

List of authorised schemes

The list—

Requirement to submit supervisory return
The Pensions Regulator may by notice require the trustees of a collectivemoney purchase scheme to submit a supervisory return.
The Secretary of State may make regulations setting out the informationthat the Pensions Regulator may require in a supervisory return.
The notice must specify—
the information required to be included in the return,
the manner and form in which the return must be submitted, and
the period (of at least 28 days) within which the return must be submitted.
The trustees of a collective money purchase scheme may not be required tosubmit a supervisory return more than once in any 12 month period.

Duty to notify the Pensions Regulator of significant events

Where a person mentioned in subsection (2) becomes aware of the fact that asignificant event has occurred in relation to an authorised collective moneypurchase scheme, the person must (subject to subsections (6) and (7)) givenotice of that fact, in writing, to the Pensions Regulator as soon asreasonably practicable.
The persons are—
a trustee of the scheme;
an employer in relation to the scheme;
a person who (alone or with others) has power to appoint or remove atrustee;
a person who (alone or with others) has power to vary the provisions of thescheme;
a person who provides legal, financial or actuarial advice in relation tothe scheme;
a person who manages the scheme administration services;
a person acting in a capacity specified in regulations made by theSecretary of State.
The Secretary of State must make regulations setting out the events thatconstitute significant events for the purposes of this section.
The Secretary of State may by regulations specify further information thatis to be provided by a person required to give notice under this section.
Except as provided by subsections (6) and (7), the disclosure ofinformation under this section does not breach—
any obligation of confidence owed by the person making the disclosure, or
any other restriction on the disclosure of information (however imposed).

This section does not require a disclosure of information if the disclosurewould contravene the data protection legislation (but in determining whether adisclosure of information would do so, take into account the duty imposed bythis section).

A person is not required by this section to disclose anything in respect ofwhich a claim to legal professional privilege (or, in Scotland, toconfidentiality of communications) could be maintained in legal proceedings.
Section 10 of the Pensions Act 1995 (civil penalties) applies to a personwho fails to comply with a requirement imposed by or under this section.
The first regulations under subsection (3) are subject to affirmativeresolution procedure.
Subsequent regulations under subsection (3), and regulations undersubsection (2)(g) or (4), are subject to negative resolution procedure.
Risk notices
The Pensions Regulator may give a risk notice to the trustees of acollective money purchase scheme if the Regulator considers that—
there is an issue of concern in relation to the scheme, and
the scheme will breach the authorisation criteria, or is likely to breachthem, if the issue is not resolved.
A risk notice is a notice that requires the trustees of the scheme tosubmit to the Pensions Regulator a plan (a “resolution plan”) setting outproposals for resolving the issue of concern.
A risk notice must—
identify the issue of concern;
specify the date by which the resolution plan is to be submitted.

If the Pensions Regulator is not satisfied that the proposals in aresolution plan are likely to be adequate to resolve the issue of concern, theRegulator may give a further notice to the trustees requiring them to submit arevised plan by a date specified in the notice.
The trustees must implement the proposals in a resolution plan if thePensions Regulator—
is satisfied that the proposals are likely to be adequate to resolve theissue of concern, and
notifies the trustees accordingly.
The Pensions Regulator may direct the trustees to comply with therequirement imposed by subsection (5).
Where the trustees are required by subsection (5) to implement theproposals in a resolution plan, the trustees must—

submit to the Pensions Regulator, before the end of a period specified inregulations made by the Secretary of State, a report setting out what progressthey are making in implementing the proposals (a “progress report”);
submit further progress reports to the Pensions Regulator at intervalsspecified by the Pensions Regulator.
Resolution plans and progress reports must be provided in the manner andform specified by the Pensions Regulator.
A reference to a resolution plan in subsections (4) to (8) includes areference to a resolution plan as revised under subsection (4).
The Secretary of State may by regulations—
specify information that a risk notice must contain;
provide that the date referred to in subsection (3)(b) or (4) must fallbefore the end of a period specified in the regulations.
Section 10 of the Pensions Act 1995 (civil penalties) applies to a trusteewho fails to comply with—
a notice under subsection (1) or (4),
a direction under subsection (6), or
a requirement imposed by subsection (7).
Regulations under this section are subject to negative resolutionprocedure.
Withdrawal of authorisation
If the Pensions Regulator stops being satisfied that an authorisedcollective money purchase scheme meets the authorisation criteria, it maydecide to withdraw the scheme’s authorisation.
A warning notice under the standard procedure or a determination noticeunder the special procedure given in relation to a decision under subsection(1) must—
explain that the issue of the notice is a triggering event (see section31), and
include an explanation of the trustees’ duties under sections 31 to 45.
On withdrawal of a scheme’s authorisation, the Pensions Regulator must—
notify the trustees that the scheme is no longer authorised, and
remove the scheme from the list of authorised collective money purchaseschemes.

notify each employer and relevant former employer, and each beneficiary, ofthe proposal and of such other matters as may be specified in regulations madeby the Secretary of State.
The ways of discharging the scheme’s liability referred to in subsection(1)(b) are—
transferring the value of the beneficiaries’ accrued rights to benefitsunder the scheme to a collective money purchase scheme or to a Master Trustscheme;

transferring the value of those rights, in such circumstances as may bespecified in regulations made by the Secretary of State, to a pension schemethat has characteristics specified in the regulations;

securing, in such circumstances as may be specified in regulations made bythe Secretary of State, the payment of benefits by such other means (an“alternative payment mechanism”) as may be specified in the regulations.

provision conferring power on the Pensions Regulator to direct trustees todo things permitted or required by the regulations;

provision about how rights conferred by the regulations may be exercised(including the time periods within which they may be exercised);

This section applies during a triggering event period for a collectivemoney purchase scheme.
The Pensions Regulator may make a pause order in relation to the scheme ifeither of the following two conditions is met.

A pause order is an order that during the period for which it has effectone or more of the following directions has effect—

a direction that no further payments (or no further payments of a specifieddescription) are to be made towards the scheme—

a direction that an amount (or specified amount) which—

Definitions
Collective money purchase benefits and schemes
For the purposes of this Part, a benefit provided under a pension scheme isa “collective money purchase benefit” if—
the benefit is a qualifying benefit (see section 53), and
the scheme is a qualifying scheme (see sections 54 and 55).
In this Part “collective money purchase scheme” means—
a qualifying scheme, or
a section of a qualifying scheme (see sections 54(6) to (9) and 56),
under which all of the benefits that may be provided are qualifying benefits.
Qualifying benefits
A benefit provided under a pension scheme is a “qualifying benefit” if—
the benefit is provided out of the available assets of the scheme,

under the rules of the scheme, the rate or amount of the benefit is subjectto periodic adjustments designed to achieve a balance between the value of theavailable assets of the scheme and the required amount, and
the benefit is not of a description specified in regulations made by theDepartment.
In subsection (1)—
* “the available assets of the scheme” means all the assets that—
arise or derive from the payments made by or in respect of members of thescheme, and
are available (subject to any deductions that fall to be made in respect ofadministration charges) for the provision of benefits to or in respect of themembers of the scheme collectively;

* “the required amount” means the amount expected to be required, applying appropriate actuarial assumptions, for the purpose of providing benefits under the scheme to or in respect of the members of the scheme collectively.
Regulations under subsection (1)(c) are subject to confirmatory procedure.
Where a scheme is divided into sections, this section has effect as if—
the reference to the scheme in subsection (1)(a) were a reference to asection of the scheme, and
the other references to the scheme were references to that section of it.
Qualifying schemes
A pension scheme is a “qualifying scheme” if it meets the requirements inthis section.

The scheme must be an occupational pension scheme established under anirrevocable trust by a person or persons to whom section 1(2)(a) (employer) ofthe Pension Schemes (Northern Ireland) Act 1993 applied when the scheme wasestablished (without other persons).
The scheme must be used, or intended to be used, only by—
a single employer, or
two or more employers that are connected with each other.
The scheme must not be a relevant public service pension scheme (seesection 55).
The qualifying benefits provided under the scheme must consist of orinclude the payment of a pension.
If the scheme provides both qualifying benefits and other benefits, theremust be appropriate separation of the qualifying benefits.
There is “appropriate separation” of qualifying benefits and other benefitsif (and only if)—
the scheme is divided into sections,
none of the sections under which qualifying benefits are provided providesother types of benefit,
payments made by or in respect of members of the scheme for the purpose ofproviding qualifying benefits under a section of the scheme are allocated tothat section, and
a proportion of the assets of the scheme is attributable to each section ofthe scheme and cannot be used for the purposes of any other section.

If the scheme provides a combination of qualifying benefits with differentcharacteristics that is described in regulations made by the Department, theremust be appropriate separation of those qualifying benefits.
There is “appropriate separation” of qualifying benefits with differentcharacteristics if (and only if)—
the scheme is divided into sections,
each of the different types of qualifying benefit is provided under adifferent section,
payments made by or in respect of members of the scheme for the purpose ofproviding qualifying benefits under a section of the scheme are allocated tothat section, and
a proportion of the assets of the scheme is attributable to each section ofthe scheme and cannot be used for the purposes of any other section.
Regulations under subsection (8) are subject to negative resolution.

For the purposes of section 54(4) a pension scheme is a relevant publicservice pension scheme if it is—

Authorisation of collective money purchase schemes
A person may not operate a collective money purchase scheme unless thescheme is authorised.

Article 10 of the [Pensions (Northern Ireland) Order 1995 (S.I. 1995/3213(N.I. 22))](/id/nisi/1995/3213?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (civilpenalties) applies to a person who breaches subsection (1).
If the Pensions Regulator becomes aware that a collective money purchasescheme is being operated without authorisation, it must notify the trustees ofthe scheme that the scheme is not authorised.
The notification must—
explain that the notification is a triggering event (see section 82), and
include an explanation of the trustees’ duties under sections 82 to 96.
For the purposes of this section a person “operates” a collective moneypurchase scheme if, in relation to the scheme, the person accepts—
money paid by a member (or prospective member), or
money paid by an employer (or prospective employer) in respect ofcontributions, fees, charges or anything else except—
the costs of setting up the scheme, or
costs relating to obtaining authorisation for the scheme.
Application for authorisation
The trustees of a collective money purchase scheme may apply to thePensions Regulator for authorisation.
An application must be made in the manner and form specified by thePensions Regulator.
An application must include—
the scheme’s viability report and viability certificate (see section 64),and
the scheme’s continuity strategy (see section 68).
The Department may by regulations—
specify other information that must be included in an application;
require a fee to be paid to the Pensions Regulator in respect of anapplication.
In considering an application, the Pensions Regulator may take into accountany matters it considers appropriate, including—
additional information provided by the applicant, and
subsequent changes to the application or to any information provided by theapplicant.
Regulations under subsection (4) are subject to negative resolution.
Decision on application

Where an application is made for authorisation of a collective moneypurchase scheme under section 59, the Pensions Regulator must decide whetherit is satisfied that the scheme meets the authorisation criteria.
The Pensions Regulator must make that decision within the period of sixmonths beginning with the day on which the Pensions Regulator received theapplication.
The authorisation criteria are—
that the persons involved in the scheme are fit and proper persons (seesection 62),
that the design of the scheme is sound (see section 63),
that the scheme is financially sustainable (see section 65),
that the scheme has adequate systems and processes for communicating withmembers and others (see section 66),
that the systems and processes used in running the scheme are sufficient toensure that it is run effectively (see section 67), and
that the scheme has an adequate continuity strategy (see section 68).
If the Pensions Regulator is satisfied that the collective money purchasescheme meets the authorisation criteria, it must—
grant the authorisation,
notify the applicant of its decision, and
add the scheme to its list of authorised collective money purchase schemes(see section 77).
If the Pensions Regulator is not satisfied that the collective moneypurchase scheme meets the authorisation criteria, it must—
refuse to grant the authorisation, and
notify the applicant of its decision.
A notification under subsection (5)(b) must also include—
the reasons for the decision, and
details of the right of referral to the First-tier Tribunal or UpperTribunal (see section 61).
Reference to Tribunal of refusal to grant authorisation
If the Pensions Regulator refuses to grant authorisation to a collectivemoney purchase scheme, the decision may be referred to the Tribunal by—
the trustees, or
any other person who appears to the Tribunal to be directly affected by thedecision.
In this section “the Tribunal”, in relation to a reference under subsection(1), means—
the First-tier Tribunal, in any case where it is determined by or underTribunal Procedure Rules that the First-tier Tribunal is to hear thereference;
the Upper Tribunal, in any other case.

Fit and proper persons requirement

This section applies for the purposes of enabling the Pensions Regulator todecide whether it is satisfied that the persons involved in a collective moneypurchase scheme are fit and proper persons (see section 60(3)(a)).
The Pensions Regulator must assess whether each of the following is a fitand proper person to act in relation to the scheme in the capacity mentioned—

a trustee;
a person who (alone or with others) has power to appoint or remove atrustee;
a person who (alone or with others) has power to vary the provisions of thescheme;
a person acting in a capacity specified in regulations made by theDepartment.
In assessing whether a person is a fit and proper person to act in aparticular capacity, the Pensions Regulator—
must take into account any matters specified in regulations made by theDepartment, and
may take into account such other matters as it considers appropriate,including matters relating to a person connected with that person.

This section applies for the purposes of enabling the Pensions Regulator todecide whether it is satisfied that the design of a collective money purchasescheme is sound (see section 60(3)(b)).
In deciding whether the design of a collective money purchase scheme issound, the Pensions Regulator must take into account—

any matters specified in regulations made by the Department.

Viability report
The trustees of a collective money purchase scheme must—
prepare a document explaining the design of the scheme and the reasons thatthey consider the design to be sound (a “viability report”), and
obtain a certificate from the scheme actuary certifying that, in theactuary’s opinion, the design of the scheme is sound (a “viabilitycertificate”).
The scheme actuary may not give a viability certificate unless satisfiedthat the scheme has rules that meet the requirements of section 69 and anyregulations under that section.
The Department may by regulations—
specify information that must be included in a viability report,
specify other requirements with which a viability report must comply,
make provision about the content of a viability certificate,
specify matters to which the scheme actuary must have regard when providinga viability certificate, and
make provision about additional information or documents that must beprepared or obtained in connection with a viability report.
The trustees of a collective money purchase scheme must, at least once ayear—
review the most recent viability report,
if appropriate, revise it, and
obtain a new viability certificate in respect of the report (or revisedreport).
If the most recent viability report becomes inaccurate or incomplete to anysignificant extent, the trustees must—
revise the report, and
obtain a new viability certificate in respect of the revised report.
The trustees must provide the Pensions Regulator with the information anddocuments listed in subsection (7)—
on applying for authorisation (see section 59),
within three months of the viability report being revised, and
at any other time, on request from the Pensions Regulator.
The information and documents to be provided are—
the most recent viability report;
the most recent viability certificate;
any additional information or documents specified or described inregulations under subsection (3)(e).

This section applies for the purposes of enabling the Pensions Regulator todecide whether it is satisfied that a collective money purchase scheme isfinancially sustainable (see section 60(3)(c)).

In order to be satisfied that a collective money purchase scheme isfinancially sustainable, the Pensions Regulator must be satisfied that thescheme has sufficient financial resources to meet the following costs—
the costs of setting up and running the scheme, and
in the event of a triggering event occurring—
the costs of complying with the duties under sections 82 to 96, and
the costs of continuing to run the scheme for such period (which must beat least six months and no more than two years) as the Pensions Regulatorthinks appropriate for the scheme.

In deciding whether it is satisfied that a scheme has sufficient financialresources to meet the costs mentioned in subsection (2), the PensionsRegulator must take into account any matters specified in regulations made bythe Department.

must take into account any matters specified in regulations made by theDepartment, and
may take into account any communications made using the systems andprocesses referred to in subsection (2).

If a triggering event occurs in relation to a collective money purchasescheme, the trustees must pursue one of the continuity options.

continuity option 1 (discharge of liabilities and winding up) (see section87);
continuity option 2 (resolving triggering event) (see section 88);
continuity option 3 (conversion to closed scheme) (see section 89).
The trustees must pursue continuity option 1—
if the triggering event is an item 1 or 2 triggering event and the decisionto withdraw authorisation has become final (see section 86), or
if the triggering event is an item 3 triggering event.
In those cases, the trustees must pursue continuity option 1 even if—
the item 1, 2 or 3 triggering event occurs within the triggering eventperiod of an earlier triggering event, and
the trustees have already decided to pursue continuity option 2 or 3 inrespect of the earlier triggering event.
The trustees may pursue continuity option 3 only if (or to the extent that)the provisions of the scheme allow them to do so.

where continuity option 1 (discharge of liabilities and winding up) is tobe pursued—

how the scheme will continue to meet the authorisation criteria;
any revisions that will be needed to the viability report and thecontinuity strategy (see sections 64 and 68).
An implementation strategy must—
include any other information specified or described in regulations made bythe Department, and
be prepared in accordance with regulations made by the Department.

This section applies during a triggering event period for a collectivemoney purchase scheme.
The Pensions Regulator may make a pause order in relation to the scheme ifeither of the following two conditions is met.
Condition 1 is that the Pensions Regulator is satisfied that making a pauseorder will help the trustees to carry out the implementation strategy.
Condition 2 is that the Pensions Regulator is satisfied that—
there is, or is likely to be if a pause order is not made, an immediaterisk to the interests of members of the scheme or the assets of the scheme,and
it is necessary to make a pause order to protect the interests of thegenerality of the members of the scheme.
A pause order is an order that during the period for which it has effectone or more of the following directions has effect—
a direction that no new members (or no new members of a specifieddescription) are to be admitted to the scheme;
a direction that no further payments (or no further payments of a specifieddescription) are to be made towards the scheme—
by or on behalf of employers or relevant former employers (or employers orrelevant former employers of a specified description), or
by or in respect of members (or members of a specified description);
a direction that an amount (or specified amount) which—
corresponds to a payment that would be due to be made towards the scheme inrespect of a member but for a direction under paragraph (b), and
has been deducted from a payment of earnings in respect of an employment,
is to be repaid to the member in question by the employer;
a direction that no benefits (or no benefits of a specified description)are to be paid to or in respect of members (or members of a specifieddescription) under the scheme rules;
a direction that—
no transfers (or no transfers of a specified description) of or in respectof a member’s rights under the scheme rules are to be made from the scheme,
no transfer payments (or no transfer payments of a specified description)in respect of a member’s rights under the scheme rules are to be made from thescheme, or
no other steps (or no other steps of a specified description) are to betaken to discharge a liability of the scheme to or in respect of a member ofthe scheme in respect of pensions or other benefits.
In subsection (5)(b)—
a reference to payments does not include payments due to be made before theorder takes effect, and
a reference to payments towards a scheme includes payments in respect ofpension credits where the person entitled to the credit is a member of thescheme.
A direction under subsection (5)(e) may provide that—
no transfers of or in respect of a member’s rights under the scheme rules,or no such transfers of a specified description, may be made from the scheme,or
no transfer payments in respect of such rights, or no such transferpayments of a specified description, may be made from the scheme,

unless the amounts paid out from the scheme in respect of the transfers ortransfer payments are determined in a specified manner and the transfers ortransfer payments satisfy such other conditions as may be specified.
A pause order may also require the trustees of the scheme to obtain anactuarial valuation within a specified period.
A pause order containing such a requirement must specify—
the date by reference to which the matters to be set out in the valuationmust be determined;
the information and statements that the valuation must contain;
any other requirements that the valuation must satisfy.
